note: The History of Mathematics: A Reader, by J. Fauvel and J. J.
publisher: Hogendijk, Jan P., Springer c Verlag. With permission of Springer. Excerpts
title: The Arabic Translation of the Lost Greek Original by G
Springer-Verlag, c Berlin Heidelberg 1976

Reprinted/adapted by permission from Springer Nature; Springer Verlag, Nicolas Chuquet, Renaissance Mathematician: A study with extensive translation of Chuquet’s mathematical manuscript completed in 1494
c D

note: Used with permission. xii Acknowledgments
title: Macmillan, in association with the Open University
We give here some suggestions for further reading covering Chapters 3–5
Euclid: the Creation of Mathematics, Springer. Useful and readable account of the thirteen Books in Euclid’s Elements
Ancient Mathematics, Science of Antiquity, Routledge. This book is remarkable for its breadth, and covers topics not included here such as mathematics among the Romans
The Mathematics of Plato’s Academy
An illuminating attempt to reconstruct the development of 4th-century BC ideas of ratio and proportion, attentive to sources and to papyral evidence
A History of Greek Mathematics, Dover
The standard two-volume general history, which is thorough and informative although some judgements need revision in the light of subsequent scholarship

note: which we only touch on in this book.
title: The Evolution of the Euclidean Elements, Reidel. A substantive study of the development and significance of incommensurable magnitudes
Figure 5.19. Frontispiece of Halley’s 1710 edition of Apollonius’s Conics

The Ancient Tradition of Geometric Problems, Dover. This book develops the discussion of the problem-solving aspect of the geometrical research tradition (notably, the three classical problems) further and more fully than we do here
Magic, Reason and Experience, Cambridge University Press. This book discusses the development of mathematics and other Greek sciences in the context of social and intellectual history
Science and Mathematics in Ancient Greek Culture, Oxford University Press. A very readable survey by several authors of the many aspects of Greek mathematics and science

container-title: An account of Greek and Indian trigonometry that reaches to the European renaissance
title: The Mathematics of the Heavens and the Earth: The Early History of Trigonometry, Princeton University Press
Heavenly Mathematics: The Forgotten Art of Spherical Trigonometry, Princeton University Press. A companion volume to the previous one, it not only teaches but motivates and excites

note: Livelier than Heath’s book, and only slightly less thorough.
title: Science Awakening
Augustine to Galileo, Penguin
a full and helpful survey of Western science in the Middle Ages

note: A readable and stimulating account that will be worth coming back to in Chapter 11.
title: Oxford Figures: Eight Centuries of The Mathematical Sciences

container-title: with particular bearing on the construction of an idea of a European mathematical tradition
title: L’Europe Mathematique, Mathematical Europe, Editions de la Maison des Sciences de l’Homme, Paris. This book has a reasonably up-to-date account of many of the topics discussed here (some in English, some in French
Science in the Middle Ages, Wiley. A most readable short survey with a useful critical bibliography

publisher: Wisconsin University Press. Scholarly and rich
title: Oresme and the Kinematics of Circular Motion, edited with an introduction, English translation and commentary

God’s Philosophers: How the Medieval World Laid the Foundations of Modern Science. Icon Books. This readable presentation does much to rescue medieval philosophers from the slurs of later generations. It gives an up-to-date account of the political and theological context in which they wrote and discusses Galileo’s work in the same spirit
Mathematics from Manuscript to Print: 1300–1600, Oxford University Press. A collection of scholarly essays on some of the topics in this chapter
Science in the Middle Ages, University of Chicago Press. A collection of essays on different topics, including a lucid essay on medieval mathematics by Michael Mahoney

The Rise of Early Modern Science, Cambridge University Press. This is a comparative study of intellectual life in the Islamic world, Europe, and China, with the aim of explaining why science arose only in Europe
Cardano, the Gambling Scholar, Dover. A highly readable account of one of mathematics’ more colourful characters
The Italian Renaissance of Mathematics, Droz. A full study of the mathematical sciences and the rediscovery of Greek mathematics in 15th- and 16thcentury Italy

From Cardano’s Great Art to Lagrange’s Reflections: Filling a Gap in the History of Algebra, European Mathematical Society: Heritage of European Mathematics. The subtitle says it all, but the filling is rich, clear, and fascinating

note: A well-illustrated account of the rise, decline, and recovery of this important institution.
title: A Brief History of Gresham College 1597–1997
John Dee: Interdisciplinary Studies in English Renaissance Thought, Springer. A set of essays examining Dee’s activities from a wide range of perspectives

The Printing Press as an Agent of Change: Communications and Cultural Transformations in early-modern Europe, Cambridge University Press. A thorough historical guide to one of the most important influences on the subject matter of this chapter
Oxford Figures: Eight Centuries of The Mathematical Sciences, second edition, Oxford University Press. A valuable source of new information for many chapters in this book
The Mathematicians’ Apprenticeship: Science, Universities and Society in England, 1560–1640, Cambridge University Press. Full of informative detail and illuminating quotations

note: including his prediction that the apocalypse would occur in the year 1700.
title: John Napier: Life, Logarithms and Legacy, Princeton University Press. As the title suggests, this not only covers Napier’s route to his discovery of logarithms but his theological work

Intellectual Origins of the English Revolution, Oxford University Press. A broad sweep by one of the most distinguished historians of the period, in which the role of mathematical practitioners is given unusually full weight

A History of Mathematics Education in England, Cambridge University Press. Only the first two chapters concern our period, but this is a readable and interesting book that looks at aspects of this subject up to the last century

note: 78 See (Stone 1973, 51).
title: Robert Recorde: Tudor Scholar and Mathematician, Scientists of Wales, University of Wales Press. An engaging account of Recorde’s difficult career in a time of religious and political dangers

Robert Recorde: the Life and Times of a Tudor Mathematician, University of Wales Press. This is both a biography and a thorough overview of his work, the influences upon it and its contributions to mathematical and scientific life

note: though short on Harriot’s mathematics.
title: Thomas Harriot: A Biography, Oxford University Press. A good guide to the breadth of Harriot’s activities, as well as to his relations with friends and colleagues

publisher: Oxford University Press., Oxford University Press
title: The Greate Invention of Algebra: Thomas Harriot’s Treatise on Equations
A masterly reconstruction of Harriot’s study of equations, with a fine short introduction

The Mathematical Practitioners of Tudor & Stuart England, Cambridge University Press. A historical survey (1485–1714) with 582 biographies of practitioners and 628 mathematical works listed briefly — a most useful work
Doctor Copernicus, Secker and Warburg. This novel, and the next, give vivid accounts of the title figures, their work and their times through the medium of fiction
Kepler: Four Hundred Years, Pergamon Press. An extensive collection of scholarly but readable articles on all aspects of Kepler’s work
The Life of Galileo
Many of the historical assertions in the play have been disputed, but it captures the drama and what can be at stake when science and power collide

Kepler’s Geometrical Cosmology, Chicago University Press. A clear, scholarly discussion of Kepler’s cosmological theories, which embrace music and astrology as well as astronomy, and their grounding in geometry and theology

The Book Nobody Read: Chasing the Revolutions of Nicolaus Copernicus, Walker. An enthralling account both of the impact of Copernicus’s great work and of how this impact was documented by many years of tracking down every surviving copy
Galileo, Oxford University Press. A fresh view of Galileo that sees him as a mathematician, a musician, an artist, a writer, a philosopher, and an instrument maker
The Copernican Revolution: Planetary Astronomy in the Development of Western Thought, Harvard University Press. A full and readable study of astronomy before Kepler

publisher: Cambridge University Press. A biography of Brahe
title: Tycho Brahe and the Astronomical Community of the Late Sixteenth Century

note: Edition), Zalta, E.N. (ed.
title: Nicolaus Copernicus, The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy
The Construction of Modern Science: Mechanisms and Mechanics, Wiley. A compact and helpful account of 17th-century science from Kepler to Newton

container-title: Editions de la Maison des Sciences de l’Homme
title: Tradition and modernity in early modern mathematics’, Viete, Descartes and Fermat
L’Europe Mathematique, Mathematical Europe
An observant disentangling and comparison of the work of the three men most responsible for algebra in the early 17th century

Redefining Geometrical Exactness: Descartes’s Transformation of the Early Modern Concept of Construction, Sources and Studies in the History of Mathematics and Physical Sciences, Springer. This work rethinks the history of mathematics in the 17th and early 18th centuries by examining closely the ideas of problems and solutions (notably, constructions) held by the mathematicians of the time. It is not an easy read, but is likely to prove one of the few books to change our ideas about this vital period in the development of mathematics
Revolution in Science, Harvard University Press. A rewarding book by one of the leading Newton scholars of his generation

container-title: European Mathematics in the Early 17th Century Co., 1925
title: Discours de la Methode pour bien Conduire sa Raison et Chercher la Verite dans les Sciences. Plus la Dioptrique, Les Meteores et la Geometrie, qui sont des Essais de cette Methode, Leyden. La Geometrie was translated as The Geometry of Rene Descartes by D.E
Open Court Publishing 452 Chapter 13
The book carries a facsimile of the first, French, edition, and is a fascinating foundational document of modern mathematics; it is also a rewarding read

container-title: The Library of the Liberal Arts, Bobbs-Merrill. A helpful guide to Descartes’s evolving conversation with himself
title: Rules for the Direction of the Mind, Philosophical essays L
Descartes: Philosophy, Mathematics and Physics, Harvester Press. An interesting set of essays, including the one by Mahoney discussed in this chapter
Descartes: an Intellectual Biography, Oxford University Press. A good introduction to Descartes which is unusual in discussing his mathematics

note: Still the only attempt to survey all of Fermat’s work in the context of his time.
title: The Mathematical Career of Pierre de Fermat, 1601–1665
Descartes’s Geometrie and revolutions in mathematics
A thoughtful and thought-provoking analysis assessing the magnitude of Descartes’s achievement
Descartes, Oxford University Press. A good and accessible intellectual biography of Descartes, giving judicious consideration to the position of mathematics in Descartes’s work as a whole
The Algebra of abu Kamil, in a commentary by Mordecai Finzi
The administration of Gresham College and its fluctuating fortunes as a scientific institution in the seventeenth century
The Algebra of Mohammed ben Musa
